instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Small water damage around L7701. No backlight.
threads.message:
Hi there,

Feedback line was missing because the pad was totally destroyed by corrosion (see the picture). 
Ran a jumper to another pad (see picture 2).
Replaced the backlight driver IC.
Still no backlight. 8.5V on the coil.
Checked <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> - was low (0.8V). Connected <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> to pin 2 instead of <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>.
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> is 2.7V
Still 8.5V on the coil and strange backlight on the screen: I dont see folder but rather a whole screen goes solid dark color.

Please help. Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Small water damage around L7701. No backlight.
threads.message:
I don't understand where did you run the wire.
It doesn't look to go as the red line marks.

When PWM is low, do PRAM 3 times first.
If still low, remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run wire from <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>.

Post diode mode to ground on all return resistors, <RESISTOR>R7717</RESISTOR>-22.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Small water damage around L7701. No backlight.
threads.message: Found the problem. Diode was soldered other way around by someone who tried to fix this board previously. Thanks for your help!
